A safeguard framework has been prepared for the Railway Energy 
Efficiency and Safety Enhancement Investment Program. The first 
tranche  is  classified  category  C  for  all  safeguards  in  accordance 
with this framework. 
 
The  investment  program  is  the  first  targeted  intervention  to 
promote  energy  efficiency,  improve  environmental  sustainability, 
and  improve  safety  in  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB) 
transport sector operations and in the PRC transport sector. This

The  investment  program  is  a  priority  investment  included  in  the 
Eleventh Five-Year Plan of the Government, 2006–2010, and the 
stimulus package announced in October 2008. 
 
This  is  the  first  time  the  multitranche  financing  facility  (MFF) 
modality will be used in the PRC transport sector. The investment 
program will be implemented in the less developed southwestern 
region, an area that is supported by ADB, and will form a part of 
the  government’s  railway  development  plan  and  its  stimulus 
package. Options for possible financing modalities were explored. 
The  use  of the  MFF  modality  is considered  the  most  appropriate 
for  financing  this  investment  program  given  the  need  to  finance 
multiple  projects  under  an  investment  program,  provide  flexible 
tranche  financing  requirements  to  suit  the  readiness  of  individual 
projects, have long-term engagement; and the strong institutional 
capacity of the Ministry of Railways (MOR), the executing agency. 
The  proposed  MFF  provides  flexibility  to  the  government  and  to 
ADB.  Since  the  development  plan  will  be  implemented  over  the 
next  7  years,  the  government  can  submit  the  periodic  financing 
request  (PFR)  when  the  projects  are  ready  to  use  these 
equipment  and  materials;  and  this  can  be  matched  with  the 
availability  of  funds  on  the  ADB  side.  The  framework  approach 
provided  an  opportunity  for  streamlining  domestic  procedures.

Because  of  the  urgency  of  implementing  the  stimulus  package, 
the  government  has  requested  approval  of  advance  contracting 
and retroactive financing of up to 20% of the first loan proceeds, 
for  expenditures  incurred  and  paid  for  but  not  earlier  than 
12 months  before  the  date  of  the  loan  agreement.  This  request 
was  approved  on  9  September  2009.  The  government  has  been 
informed  that  provision  of  advance  contracting  and  procurement 
and  retroactive  financing  does  not  commit  ADB  to  finance  the 
tranches.  For  subsequent  tranches,  retroactive  financing  of 
otherwise eligible expenditures may be considered and allowed by 
ADB  Management  when  included  in  a  PFR.  Total  retroactive 
financing  will  not  exceed  an  amount  equivalent  to  20%  of  the 
individual  loan  and  must  have  been  incurred  not  more  that 
12 months before the signing of the related legal agreements. 
 
The  investment  program  will  be  implemented  over  7  years.  The 
number of PFRs will be from three to six. The disbursement of the 
first  PFR  is  expected  to  be  completed  by  30  June  2016.  The 
disbursement  of  the  last  tranche  will  be  completed  no  later  than 
30 June 2017.

All  procurement  to  be  financed  under  the  MFF  ADB  loan  will  be 
carried  out  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines 
(2007, as amended from time to time). The procurement plan for

The  investment  program  will  (i) reduce  fuel  consumption  and 
enhance  energy  efficiency,  enabling  the  PRC  to  save  valuable 
foreign  exchange,  (ii)  improve  the  environment  and  reduce 
pollution;  (iii) enhance  railway  safety,  enabling  railway  users  to 
benefit  from  lower  transport  costs;  (iv) increase  the  line  capacity, 
benefiting  consumers  and  producers  of  goods  and  services 
through the provision of timely and efficient transport services and 
lower  logistics  costs;  and  (v) improve  staff  productivity,  enabling 
railway users to benefit from lower costs.  
 
The  major  project  beneficiaries  will  be  (i)  the  government,  which 
will benefit from improved safety, reduced economic losses, and a 
reduced  energy  bill;  (ii)  passengers,  who  will  benefit  from 
affordable, environment-friendly, faster, and safer trips; (iii) freight 
shippers, who will benefit from reduced damage to shipments and 
more affordable, faster, and safer trips; and (iv) private sector who 
will  benefit 
job  opportunities  and 
enhanced economic competitiveness. 
 
Railway  development  generates  job  opportunities  (skilled  and 
unskilled)  for  the  poor,  ethnic  minorities,  women,  and  other 
vulnerable  groups,  which  helps  develop  their  job  skills.  Job 
opportunities will provide potential new sources of income for local 
residents.  An  increase  in  female  participation  in  the  labor  and 
tourism  market  increases  women’s  net  income  and  savings, 
improves  overall  family  welfare,  and  helps  improve  women’s 
status.  Women  and  other  vulnerable  groups  benefit  from  railway 
development  and  have  equal  access  to  employment  and  wages. 
Railway  development  generates  demand  for  local  labor  and 
increases worker productivity and wages. Expansion of secondary 
and  tertiary  industries  helps  generate  additional  employment 
opportunities for both men and women, close to their homes.  
 
The investment program is formulated to minimize potential risks. 
Sensitivity  tests  indicate  that  there  would  have  to  be  a  sharp 
deterioration  in  economic  circumstances  for  the  investment 
program  to  lose  economic  viability.  A  potential  risk  is  delay  in 
implementation,  which  would  delay  the  realization  of  benefits. 
MOR has successfully implemented ADB-financed projects. Risks 
associated with potential changes in government policy for railway 
development  are  minimal.  An  analysis  of  the  demand  for  railway 
transport  shows  that  the  southwestern  PRC  needs  additional 
railway  transport  capacity  to  sustain  its  economic  development. 
Macroeconomic conditions  are expected to continue to be sound, 

 

 with  continuing  political  stability  in  the  PRC.  Strong  economic 
performance  is  expected  in  the  southwestern  PRC  based  on  the 
government’s projections and its growth trends. 
 
The  equipment  and  materials  to  be  procured  and  included  in 
tranche  1  are  based  on  proven  and  established  technologies. 
MOR  has  experience  of  installing  new  technologies  successfully 
and  these  can  be  implemented  within  a  relatively  short  time.  For 
subsequent tranches, equipment and material with similar proven 
energy efficiency, environmental benefits, and safety benefits will 
be used. Thus, the technical risks of the investment program are 
minimal.

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

 
A. 
 
2. 
From 1978, when market-oriented economic reforms were introduced, through to 2008, 
the PRC has experienced sustained rapid economic growth that has resulted in a rapid increase 
in  demand  for  transportation.  Annual  growth  in  passenger  transport  was  9%  and  freight 
transport grew at 7.6% during 1978–2008. Railway is the principal mode of freight transport in 
the  PRC.  In  2008,  the  modal  split  for  freight  ton-kilometers  (km)  was  45.2%  for  railways, 
followed  by  29.6%  for  inland  waterways  and  seashore  shipping,  21.1%  for  roads,  3.3%  for 
pipelines,  and  0.2%  for  civil  aviation.  In  2008,  road  traffic  accounted  for  53.3%  of  total 
passenger-km,  followed  by  railways  with  33.4%,  civil  aviation  with  12.9%,  and  coastal  and 
inland waterways with 3.5%. 
 
The railway is the primary mode of long-distance and bulk transport. At the end of 2008, 
3. 
the  PRC’s  79,700  route-km  of  railways  comprised  64,000  km  of  national  railways  and 
15,700 km  of  joint  venture  and  local  railways.  The  Ministry  of  Railways  (MOR)  runs  the  state-
owned national railway as an integrated system. The joint venture and local railways, regional 
lines within provincial boundaries, are built under provincial government or MOR sponsorship to 
serve  local  needs  and  interconnect  with  the  national  railway  network.  Despite  its  large  size, 
however, the railway network does not provide adequate coverage for the country’s population 
and land area.1  
 
4. 
PRC  railways  have  the  highest  freight  transport  density  in  the  world  and  the  second 
highest passenger transport density after Japan. Locomotive turnover is the highest in the world. 
From 1978 to 2008, railway freight increased from 535 billion ton-km to 2,482 billion ton-km, or 
by 5.25% yearly, and passenger traffic grew by 6.74% yearly, from 109 billion passenger-km to 
778 billion  passenger-km.  For  passenger  trips,  the  average  railway  journey  increased  from 
134 km in 1978 to 536 km in 2008, compared with road travel, which grew from 35 km to 56 km 
over the same period. For freight, the average railway journey in 2008 was 778 km, compared 
with  69 km  for  road  transport.  Yet,  despite  such  growth  rates,  railway  capacity  has  lagged 
behind  demand  because  of  constraints  in  the  system.2 Given  the  railway’s  important  role  in 
providing economic transportation, these constraints will need to be removed. The Government 
of the PRC has therefore adopted an aggressive plan to improve the railways, and has planned 
network expansion and capacity enhancements in underserved areas.

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

1. 

Government Strategy 

 
The government’s railway development policy puts emphasis on (i) removing constraints 
5. 
and expanding the system, (ii) encouraging the construction of joint venture and local railways 
to promote the development of local economies, (iii) improving the efficiency and safety of the 
existing  system  by  using  new  technology  and  modern  management  tools  in  planning  and 
operation,  (iv)  reducing  operating  subsidies  through  appropriate  pricing  and  commercialization 
of  services,  (v)  initiating  institutional  and  structural  reforms  to  increase  autonomy  and 
accountability,  and  (vi)  encouraging  nongovernment  investment  in  infrastructure  and  related 
services.  
 
6. 
In  2004,  the  State  Council  approved  a  railway  development  plan  for  the  period  up  to 
2020, which was updated in 2008. The plan seeks to expand the railway network to 120,000 km 
by  2020.  Increasing  train  speed  is  a  major  goal.  Priority  will  be  given  to  the  development  of 
railways in unserved areas and regions that lack transport and have remained less developed. 
Route network length in the western region of the PRC will increase by 16,000 km–40,000 km 
by  2020.  To  improve  operating  efficiency,  MOR  has  begun  to  separate  passenger  and  freight 
trains on key rail corridors.3  
 
The  Eleventh  Five-Year  Plan  (11th  FYP),  2006–2010,  highlights  railway  development 
7. 
and accelerated railway construction. It foresees (i) the construction of 17,000 km of new lines 
for  a  total  network  length  of  92,000  route-km,  and  (ii)  the  conversion  of  45%  of  the  network 
length  into  double-track  electrified  railway.  The  plan  seeks  to  (i)  build  a  dedicated  passenger 
railway  network  through  the  construction  of  7,000  km  of  passenger-dedicated  lines  by  2010; 
(ii) develop coal transport corridors by increasing the capacity of the existing lines; (iii) expand 
the railway network in the poor western region (to 34,000 km); (iv) build international corridors at 
the  southwest  and  northwest  borders;  and  (v)  develop  a  nationwide  intermodal  container 
network.  A  total  investment  of  CNY1.5  trillion  (about  $200 billion)—CNY1.25  trillion  for 
construction and CNY250 billion for rolling stock—is planned in the 11th FYP, of which a total of 
CNY765.2 billion has been spent in 2006, 2007, and 2008 (Appendix 3). 
 
8. 
In  view  of  the  downturn  in  the  international  economy,  the  government  adopted  an 
aggressive plan to boost internal demand and consumption, and declared a stimulus package in 
October 2008. The stimulus package emphasizes railway development. For 2009–2012, a total 
investment  of  CNY1.5  trillion  is  envisaged  for  railway  development  in  poor,  unserved  areas—
particularly  in  the  western  region. 4  These  investments  would  include  new  construction, 
upgrading  of  existing  lines,  double  tracking,  electrification,  and  upgrading  and  building  new 
terminals.  Given  this  background,  the  government  requested  the  Asian  Development  Bank 
(ADB) to provide an investment program to support railway development in the less developed 
southwestern region.5 ADB proposes to provide this support by use of the MFF modality, which 
will be used for the first time in the PRC transport sector.

d. 

Sector Reforms 

18. 
ADB is supporting the institutional reform of the railway sector to separate government 
and enterprise functions, giving full play to market forces and increasing the competitiveness of 
the railways. ADB has actively pursued (i) the separation of the core transport business from the 
noncore transport business, (ii) the segmentation of passenger and freight services, and (iii) the 
strengthening  of  the  recently  corporatized  specialized  transportation  companies.  As  part  of 
ADB’s  policy  dialogue  with  MOR,  three  large  companies  handling  containers,  special  goods, 
and  express  parcel  have  been  set  up.13 The  establishment  of  passenger-dedicated  corridors 
with  a  separate  institutional  structure  is  a  key  ADB  intervention. 14  With  ADB  assistance, 
institutional, marketing, business development, and technical standards have been worked out 
for such initiatives; and capacity-building support was provided to officials of MOR.15 
 
19. 
The streamlining of transportation and non-transportation staff is also being pursued. On 
18  March  2005,  under  a  major  restructuring  exercise,  MOR  abolished  41 sub-railway 
administration bureaus, thereby doing away with one tier of railway management. By the end of 
2008, the number of stations and sections had been reduced from 1,500 to 627. This move has 
trimmed the staff by more than 22,000 and helped rationalize operations, improve productivity, 
and  increase  efficiency.  Recent  ADB  support  for  reforms  in  operations  and  railway  safety 
includes a sector-wide intervention for the introduction of an emergency management system, 
safe  and  reliable  technology,  improved  speeds,  dedicated  passenger  and  freight  lines,  a 
modern  dispatch  control  system,  and  high-quality  information  systems  on  the  PRC  railway 
network.  The  PRC’s  accession  to  the  World  Trade  Organization  has  intensified  competition 
among  the  different  modes  of  transport,  and  the  structure  of  transport  demand  is  likely  to 
change.16 ADB advisory TA for policy reform support to MOR17 analyzed (i) the conflicting roles 
of  meeting  social  obligations  and  making  profits,  (ii)  the  increasing  modal  competition,  (iii) the 
impact of fast urbanization and economic development, and (iv) the demand for better services. 
As  a  lead  development  partner  in  the  sector,  ADB  maintains  close  coordination  with  AFD, 
German development cooperation through KfW, and the World Bank; and has developed with 
these institutions a common approach to reforms and assistance (Appendix 3).

e. 

Marketing and Business Development 

20. 
As the PRC progresses toward a market-driven economy, its railways need to compete 
on  the  basis  of  price  and  service  quality  for  demand-based  transportation  services.  New 
marketing  and  business  development  initiatives  are  needed  for  both  freight  and  passenger 
services to be competitive. In past projects, ADB has financed project-specific studies to create 
marketing and business development opportunities, including the skills and knowledge needed 
for  market-oriented,  profitable  operations.  ADB  has  supported  the  development  of  marketing 
and business strategies for dedicated passenger lines (footnote 15), 7,000 km of which will be 
completed by 2010. The first dedicated passenger line from Beijing to Tianjin started operation 
in August 2008 and has adopted recommendations of this TA.

Lessons Learned 

 
23. 
The evaluation of ADB assistance for the PRC transport sector concluded that the ADB 
program for railways has been successful. 23 The evaluation noted that in the railway subsector, 
ADB strategic priorities were well aligned with PRC needs. Its overall focus of building railways 
using  modern  technologies  addressed  needs  to  increase  railway  capacity  and  reduce  the 
persistent gap between demand and supply as quickly and efficiently as possible. ADB’s priority 
of  improving  efficiency  and  commercial  orientation,  and  its  emphasis  on  restructuring  and 
reforming policy, was well matched to evolving institutional reforms in railways. Experience from 
completed  and  ongoing  ADB-financed  railway  projects  in  the  PRC  shows  strong  commitment 
and  generally  satisfactory  capabilities  of  executing  agencies  for  project  implementation.  The 
speed of implementation has generally exceeded expectations at appraisal, and agencies have 
generally  complied  with  loan  covenants.  Resettlement  and  environmental  management  were 
carried  out  satisfactorily.  Audit  covenants  were  complied  with  in  a  timely  manner,  and  the 
audited  financial  statements  were  generally  acceptable.  Of  the  17  ADB-supported  railway 
projects, 10 have been completed and 7 are under implementation. 
 
24. 
The key lessons from the completed railway projects highlight the need to (i) ensure that 
the executing agency—established for project processing, implementation, and operation—has 
adequate  capacity;  (ii)  prepare  realistic  traffic  forecasts;  (iii)  review  constraints  to  traffic  on  a 
network basis, and the impact on project viability of the existing and/or planned railway lines and 
other  transportation  modes  that  may  compete  with  project  facilities;  (iv) prepare  realistic 
resettlement  projections  at  appraisal;  and  (v)  finance  railway  projects  with  appropriately 
determined debt–equity ratios.

26.  MOR  will  implement  a  plan  for  railway  development  (2009–2016)  at  a  cost  of  about

plan, one option was to support railway construction or capacity expansion as has been done in

Within  this  plan,  ADB  identified  an  investment  program  of  $3.24  billion  to  support  these  three 
areas, for which it will provide support of $1 billion through the proposed MFF. The cost of the 
equipment is small compared to the cost of other capital assets or construction of a railway line, 
but  their  benefits  are  significant  and  it  is  easy  to  integrate  them  when  the  government  is 
implementing  the  development  plan.  This  would  have  high  value  added  with  a  smaller 
investment, leveraging much more value addition. 
 
27. 
The  proposed  investment  program  is  consistent  with  two  of  the  four  pillars  of  ADB’s 
country partnership strategy of the PRC:30 (i) inclusive growth and balanced development, and 
(ii) resource efficiency and environmental sustainability. The investment program encompasses 
(i) network  development,  which  will  enhance  capacity  and  reduce  bottlenecks;  (ii)  improved 
energy  efficiency  and  environmental  sustainability  by  providing  a  more  efficient  and 
environment-friendly mode of transport in the region; (iii) enhanced safety through the provision 
of a reliable and safe mode of transport; (iv) support for the PRC railway development plan and 
the western region development strategy; and (v) promotion of pro-poor economic growth in the 
region, thereby reducing poverty.

region is the lowest in the PRC, and local governments and people living in the region see the 
railway as a key investment for addressing this problem. Railway development is a part of the

A. 

Economic Analysis 

The  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  was  calculated  by  comparing  with-  and 
58. 
without-project  situations,  using  constant  2009  economic  prices.  The  investment  program  will 
introduce new and modern technology for promoting energy efficiency, improving environmental 
sustainability, and enhancing safety. Economic costs include costs for materials and equipment, 
including  installation  and  commissioning.  Economic  benefits  include  (i)  user  cost  savings  for 
diverted freight and passenger traffic; (ii) time savings for diverted passenger and freight traffic 
from  buses,  trucks,  and  waterways;  (iii)  time  savings  for  base  freight  and  passenger  traffic 
caused  by  operational  improvements;  (iv)  pollution  reduction  benefits;  (v)  energy  savings; 
(vi) avoided  road  infrastructure  and  maintenance  costs;  and  (vii)  avoided  road  accidents.  The 
EIRR  for  the  investment  program  is  estimated  at  26.81%  (Appendix  16).  Sensitivity  analysis 
tested  eight  scenarios  to  assess  the  robustness  of  the  results  of  the  economic  analysis.  The 
initial capital cost would have to be more than 304% higher than estimated for the EIRR to fall 
below  the  cutoff  rate  of  12%.  Considering  the  experience  of  ADB-financed  projects  in  the 
railway  sector,  this  switching  value  is  unlikely  to  occur.  The  freight  benefits  would  have  to 
decrease  more  than  92%  to  make  the  investment  program  economically  nonviable.  A  1-year 
delay  in  completion  does  not  affect  economic  viability.  Combinations  of  adverse  effects  of 
benefits  and  costs  were  also  tested.  The  results  showed  that  the  investment  program  would 
maintain its economic viability under plausible scenarios of variability.

D. 

Social, Poverty, and Gender Aspects 

The links between poverty, topography, and poor transport systems are apparent in the 
61. 
southwestern  PRC.  Poverty  in  this  area  is  caused  by  (i)  adverse  environmental  and  weather 
conditions and limited farmland (e.g., mountains, cold weather, water scarcity, and soil erosion); 
(ii) geographical  remoteness  and  isolation  and  high  transport  costs;  and  (iii)  lack  of  access  to 
markets, and good social and health care facilities. Providing an energy-efficient, environment-
friendly, safe, and secure transportation system enables the efficient flow of people and goods; 
conserves  resources;  protects  the  environment  from  pollution;  and  is  an  essential  component 
for  a  healthy  population,  a  high  quality  of  life,  and  a  prosperous  economy.  The  investment 
program,  when  implemented,  will  help  increase  standards  of  living  and  reduce  poverty  in  the 
southwestern  PRC  by  removing  a  transport  constraint  to  sustainable  economic  growth. 
Providing  efficient,  affordable  railway  transportation  in  underserved,  less  developed  areas  will 
create the conditions necessary for developing local resources and generating employment and 
income-enhancing opportunities.

The investment program will (i) reduce fuel consumption and enhance energy efficiency, 
enabling the PRC to save valuable foreign exchange, (ii) improve the environment and reduce 
pollution;  (iii) enhance  railway  safety,  enabling  railway  users  to  benefit  from  lower  transport 
costs; (iv) increase the line capacity, benefiting consumers and producers of goods and services 
through  the  provision  of  timely  and  efficient  transport  services  and  lower  logistics  costs;  and

Key  features.  Despite  government  efforts  to  increase  the  country’s  transport  capacity,

MANAGEMENT OF RAILWAY SAFETY 

 
1. 
Managing safety is an important aspect of reliable transportation and critical to providing 
a  competitive,  high  quality,  and  safe  mode  of  transport  to  people  and  goods.  The  People’s 
Republic  of  China  (PRC),  a  country  with  diverse  geology  and  a  challenging  environment,  has 
two-thirds  of  its  area  threatened  by  floods,  nearly  half  of  the  cities  located  in  the  seismic  belt, 
more mountainous areas than plain areas, great elevation differences between east and west, 
frequent  geological  disasters  such  as  landslides  and  flow  of  debris,  frequent  typhoons  in  the 
southern part, frequent sandstorms and windstorms in the western part, and snowstorms in the 
northern part. PRC railways crisscross the length and breadth of the country, and this working 
environment makes managing safety on the PRC railways a technical and human challenge.  
 
The  Government  of  the  PRC  and  the  Ministry  of  Railways  (MOR)  attach  great 
2. 
importance  to  rail  transport  safety,  and  it  is  an  important  cornerstone  of  the  PRC  railway 
development strategy. Safety is an inherent element underlying all planned modernization and 
technological  upgrading  on  PRC  railways.  It  is  supported  through  various  development  plans, 
such  as  the  five-year  plans,  annual  development  plans,  and  the  long-term  railway  network 
development plan 2020, which include strategy and investments in the important area of railway 
safety.  
 
The  railway  development  plan,  which  lays  down  an  ambitious  blueprint  of  railway 
3. 
network  development  until  2020,  envisages  that  safety  of  rail  transport  services  shall  be 
ensured by (i) strictly adhering to safety regulations, (ii) improving staff education and technical 
skills  through  training,  (iii)  upgrading  technology  and  modernizing  equipment  for  railway 
operation and safety, and (iv) strengthening responsibility and accountability for safety in railway 
transport.

comprises 
four  provinces  (Guangxi,  Guizhou,  Sichuan,  and  Yunnan)  and  Chongqing 
Municipality,  was  forecast  for  freight  and  passengers  in  two  categories  differentiated  by  their 
economic impact: (i) base (normal) traffic that will benefit from improved operational efficiency, 
represented by an increase in the average speed of freight and passenger trains as a result of 
the new technologies introduced by the investment program; and (ii) freight traffic diverted from 
roads  and  waterways,  and  passenger  traffic  diverted  from  roads  as  a  result  of  additional  line 
capacity  available  in  the  southwestern  region  railway  network  as  a  result  of  the  new 
technologies introduced by the investment program. The traffic forecast was based on a two-tier

components.
Traffic projections considered expected economic growth, increase in new rail line 
development in the southwestern region as part of the economic stimulus program, and market 
surveys and assessments of technical assistance consultants and the Asian Development Bank 
missions.  
 
2. 
The  railway  network  length  in  the  southwestern  region  is  forecast  to  increase  from 
11,344 kilometers (km) as of the beginning of 2008 (14.6% of the national railway network) to 
17,939  km  (18.7%  of  the  national  network)  by  2015  (Table  A16.1).  This  represents  annual 
growth of 5.9% compared to the national rail network growth of 2.6% per year during the same 
2008–2015 period. After 2015, the national network length is expected to grow by 0.8% annually 
while the regional network length is projected to grow by 2.5% per year. As a result, the base 
(normal)  traffic  in  the  southwestern  region  will  increase  from  271.16  million  tons  in  2007  to 
492.79  million  tons  in  2015.  The  share  of  the  southwestern  region  in  national  railway  freight 
traffic  will  increase  from  10.3%  in  2007  to  13.3%  in  2015  in  terms  of  tons  and  from  11.0%  to 
14.2% in terms of ton-km. By 2035, freight traffic in the region is forecast to reach 1.18 billion 
tons (18.4% of total railway freight traffic). 
 
3. 
Regional passenger traffic will experience similar growth from 147.7 million passengers 
in  2007  to  1.71  billion  passengers  by  2035.  The  share  of  passengers  in  the  national  railway 
traffic is expected to increase from 11.5% in 2007 to 14.8% in 2015 and 20.5% in 2035. In terms 
of  passenger-km,  the  corresponding  values  are  9.3%  in  2007,  11.9%  in  2015,  and  16.5%  in 
2035.  These  growth  trends  are  consistent  with  the  government’s  western  region  development 
strategy.  
 
4. 
Diverted  freight  traffic  is  expected  to  be  19.05  billion  ton-km  in  2016,  increasing  to 
26.61 billion ton-km by 2020 and 70.78 billion ton-km by 2035. Some 80% of the diverted traffic 
is assumed to be from roads, with the remaining amount from waterways. In terms of passenger 
traffic,  the  diversion  is  assumed  to  be  from  roads  only  since  the  share  of  waterways  in

I.  POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A.  Link to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
The  proposed  investment  program  is  consistent  with  two  of  the  four  pillars  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  country 
partnership  strategy  for  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC): a  (i)  inclusive  growth  and  balanced  development,  and 
(ii) resource efficiency and environmental sustainability. The investment program reflects (i) network development, which will 
enhance  capacity  and  reduce  bottlenecks;  (ii)  improved  energy  efficiency  and  environmental  sustainability,  by  providing  a 
more efficient and environment-friendly mode of transport in the region; (iii) enhanced safety through the provision of a reliable 
and safe mode of transport; (iv) support for the PRC railway development plan and the western region development strategy; 
and (v) promotion of pro-poor economic growth in the region, thereby reducing poverty. The investment program emphasizes 
energy conservation, environmental sustainability, and safety through the introduction of safe and reliable technology on the 
railway  network,  which  will  result  in  improved  reliability,  higher  mobility,  increased  network  capacity,  optimal  use  of  the 
network and assets, and increased staff productivity. All of these will lead to higher efficiency of the railway network.  
Energy-efficient, environment-friendly,  and safe railway transport  will  benefit all  passengers. The poor  will benefit equally  or 
more from the intervention.  
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                                       Targeting Classification: General intervention 
 
1.  Key Issues  
 
The  links  between  poverty,  topography,  and  poor  transport  systems  are  apparent  in  the  southwestern  PRC.  Poverty  in  this 
area is caused by adverse environmental and weather conditions and limited farmland (e.g., mountains, cold weather, water 
scarcity,  and  soil  erosion);  geographical  remoteness  and  isolation  and  high  transport  costs;  and  lack  of  access  to  markets, 
good education, and health care facilities. Railway network development has direct and indirect impacts for poor families to 
(i) move away from unsustainable, mountainous farmlands; (ii) have better access to markets, and advanced educational and 
health facilities, especially for women; and (iii) build a sustainable future in centers of economic activity. 
 
2.  Design Features  
The  investment  program  will  be  implemented  in  the  southwestern  PRC,  a  relatively  poor  area.  The  region  is  largely 
mountainous  with  abundant  natural  reserves  of  coal,  and  other  nonferrous  materials;  and  famous  tourist  sites.  In  spite  of 
abundant natural resources, many people are poor and the economic growth necessary to reduce rural poverty has failed to 
develop  because  of  inadequate  transport  services  and  high  costs.  The  railway  density  is  the  lowest  in  the  region  and  local 
governments  and  people  living  in  the  region  see  the  railway  as  a  key  investment  for  addressing  this  problem.  Railway 
development is part of the government’s program for the integrated development of transportation facilities in this poor region 
and the Ministry of Railways (MOR) plans to develop 6,500 kilometers (km) of railways in the region by 2015. The proposed 
region  also  shares  borders  with  Viet  Nam,  and  Yunnan  and  Guangxi  provinces  are  part  of  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion. 
The development of railways is expected to play an important role in facilitating and integrating this poor and underdeveloped 
region,  and  stimulating  regional  and  interprovincial  trade  and  movement  of  people.  The  investment  program  is  a  priority 
investment included in the government’s proposed Eleventh Five-Year Plan and the stimulus package announced in October 
2008.  
 

II.  SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
The interior regions of the PRC have not benefited as much from economic growth and reforms as the east coast; in fact, the 
gap between economic and social development in those regions has increased. Transport constraints and high logistics costs 
contribute  to  the  economic  disparities  between  the  regions  and  prevent  the  southwestern  region  from  capitalizing  on  its 
comparative advantages. 
 
The  impact  of  the  proposed  investment  program  will  be  an  improved  transport  system  in  the  region  that  supports 
socioeconomic development and the western region development strategy. Providing economic railway transportation in less 
developed  and  poor  areas  will  create  conditions  for  developing  local  resources,  employment  opportunities,  and  higher 
incomes; and thus contribute to improved living standards for people in the southwestern PRC.
